references: LASP is a lossless approach that greatly reduces traffic by saving the transmission of redundant parameters. Table I shows that 999â€°Â of traffic is saved on a typical CNN.

For resource-constrained industrial devices, we used a lightweight CNN network composed of two convolutional layers and two fully connected layers with a total of â„³=6.68Ã—106â„³6.68superscript106\mathcal{M}=6.68\times 10^{6} parameters, where the classifier has about â„³c=6.3Ã—103subscriptâ„³ğ‘6.3superscript103\mathcal{M}_{c}=6.3\times 10^{3} parameters (see Table I).

(e) Effects of LASP. It is time-consuming to synchronize all parameters in all rounds in resource-constrained industrial networks. For example, in Table IV, FedAvg takes 1262 hours to achieve 70% accuracy, and even HFedMS-S takes 82 hours. To alleviate the communication bottleneck, LASP blocks the transmission of redundant parameters and saves 999â€°Â of transfer bytes in calibration rounds (see Table I). For overall performance, as shown in Table IV, LASP-enabled HFedMS-D achieves up to 67% savings in transfer bytes compared to HFedMS-S, and thus reduces runtime by nearly 70%. For the setting of the round interval Tğ‘‡T, the overall performance reaches the best when T=5ğ‘‡5T=5, at this time, the FL system has the highest accuracy, the shortest runtime, the fewest rounds, and the lowest communication cost.

references: Table III gives the numerical results. It can be seen that HFedMSÂ achieves significant performance improvements under both the stream and static non-i.i.d. data settings. For the static non-i.i.d. data, HFedMS-S improves the benchmark accuracy by 2.2%âˆ¼similar-to\sim6.7%. Nevertheless, this is not all of HFedMS, as HFedMS-S does not have SCC and LASP enabled. The more advanced HFedMS-D achieves a more significant breakthrough underlying streaming non-i.i.d. data. In this setting, HFedMS-D outperforms the benchmarks by 6.4%âˆ¼similar-to\sim14.1% and maintains a satisfactory accuracy of 84.2%, while the benchmark accuracy drops by 4.3%âˆ¼similar-to\sim10%. Nonetheless, HFedMS-D has not converged to the optimum, and if we continue to train HFedMS-D until convergence, we can obtain a better result of 85.9%. These results demonstrate that HFedMS-S is strongly robust to data heterogeneity, and its advanced version HFedMS-D is also very suitable for processing dynamic streaming data.

(d) Effects of SCC.
Although HFedMS-S has shown exciting performance, it is still not enough to handle streaming non-i.i.d. data. In Table IV, HFedMS-S and HFedMS-D(T=5) achieve 70% accuracy after similar rounds, however, this is an unfair comparison for HFedMS-D as it runs only 7 full synchronization rounds, while the remaining 27 rounds of calibration only update the classifier. For a fair comparison, we use the total number of updated parameters as the x-axis to compare the convergence performance. From Figure 10, we can see that HFedMS-D converges much faster on streaming non-i.i.d. data. This is expected as HFedMS-S is not optimized for the learning forgetting problem, which is also our motivation to introduce SCC and propose a more advanced HFedMS-D.

(e) Effects of LASP. It is time-consuming to synchronize all parameters in all rounds in resource-constrained industrial networks. For example, in Table IV, FedAvg takes 1262 hours to achieve 70% accuracy, and even HFedMS-S takes 82 hours. To alleviate the communication bottleneck, LASP blocks the transmission of redundant parameters and saves 999â€°Â of transfer bytes in calibration rounds (see Table I). For overall performance, as shown in Table IV, LASP-enabled HFedMS-D achieves up to 67% savings in transfer bytes compared to HFedMS-S, and thus reduces runtime by nearly 70%. For the setting of the round interval Tğ‘‡T, the overall performance reaches the best when T=5ğ‘‡5T=5, at this time, the FL system has the highest accuracy, the shortest runtime, the fewest rounds, and the lowest communication cost.
